TopicTitle: Building a rocket to safely reach the moon and back

Articles.Content:
Yes I'm new. Anyway I've decided to  build myself a probe to test if I can get myself up there and back. Problem is just when the SRBs cut off and are decoupled, my rocket wobbles and, yes, flips. I can usually get control over it but I feel like it must be a waste of fuel. My guess is the centre of mass changes when 4 boosters are dropped. Can someone help explain this and how I can fix it? 

Also I do have a reaction wheel equipped and SAS slammed on. Thank you.

EDIT: Alright so I've made a few adjustments, and it seemed like the srbs kept slightly nudging my rocket after they were disengaged. It's working alright now though.

Thanks everyone for the help!

Edited September 17, 2017 by Urses

Well, flipping in general can be assigned to having too much drag ahead of the CoM, and not enough behind the CoM. So when you are dropping your SRBs, you are probably losing a big source of drag behind your CoM.

So, yes, as said above -- adding stuff at the back end to promote stability, and moving the CoM forward are the typical answers.

Chances are there are 4 radially-attached boosters down low.  They add a fair bit of thrust, but also quite a bit of drag very low on the rocket.  By the time they're ready to detach they're very light, so mass isn't much of a consideration.  Fins will help, draining your fuel from the bottom up will help, redesigning your payload might help.

@MajorMushroom, I think you'll find this helpful. It's probably the most effective tutorial I've ever seen. I had heard the explanation of the problem and the solution to it, but seeing it in picture form described it in a way that words simply can't compare with. After seeing this thread, I never had trouble with rocket flipping again. I highly recommend giving it a look.

If 4 staged boosters leave you with a center booster that flips while still inside the atmosphere then it is likely drag related. Put 3x fins in symmetry on the center booster. You only need 3, but 4 if you can't angle them without hitting the other boosters. Also pressing F1 makes a screenshot in the 'screenshot' folder in your KSP directory.
Probably in the 'steamapps', Program files or respective 'Downloads' folders in either Linux or Mac.

Best is a upright screenshot of the vessel with the Center of mass, Center of Thrust and Center of lift indicators activated in the vehicle assembly building. These will be the yellow, blue and pruple orbs represented. This will most likely get you the short answer without us having to pluck your brain with troubleshoot guided questions.
